festival_practices.definition: Festivals in Sanatana Dharma are sacred occasions that celebrate cosmic principles, deities, and seasonal changes, combining spiritual, cultural, and social dimensions.

origin.purpose: To honor deities, express gratitude, and reinforce Dharma in community life.

diwali.significance: Festival of Lights symbolizing victory of light over darkness.
practices: Lighting oil lamps (Deepa) in homes and temples.
Lakshmi Puja for wealth and prosperity.

navaratri.significance: Nine nights dedicated to Goddess Durga and her forms.
practices: Daily worship of different forms of Devi.
Garba and Dandiya dance in Western India.

janmashtami.significance: Celebrates the birth of Lord Krishna.
practices: Midnight puja and chanting of Krishna's names.
Dahi Handi (breaking curd pot) in Maharashtra.

maha_shivaratri.significance: Night of Shiva, symbolizing spiritual awakening.
practices: Offering Bilva leaves and water to Shiva Lingam.

spring.name: Holi
spring.significance: Festival of colors marking the arrival of spring and victory of good over evil.

spring.name: Vasant Panchami
spring.significance: Dedicated to Goddess Saraswati, marking the onset of spring.

summer.name: Ratha Yatra
summer.significance: Chariot festival of Lord Jagannath in Odisha.

winter.name: Makar Sankranti
winter.significance: Harvest festival marking sun's transition into Capricorn.

symbolism: Light represents knowledge and removal of ignorance.
Fasting purifies body and mind for spiritual focus.

modern_relevance.community: Festivals strengthen social bonds and cultural identity.
modern_relevance.sustainability: Promotes eco-friendly practices in modern celebrations.

key_scriptural_references.quote_summary: Seasonal rituals maintain harmony with cosmic order.
Offerings and devotion purify the mind and lead to liberation.
